lines.text:
[singing]
Winds in the east, mist coming in. / Like somethin' is brewin' and bout to begin. / Can't put me finger on what lies in store, / But I fear what's to happen all happened before.
You know, you *can* say it backwards, which is "docious-ali-expi-istic-fragil-cali-rupus" - but that's going a bit too far, don't you think?
Indubitably!
Oh, Bert, we're so frightened.
Now, now, don't take on so. Bert will take care of you. Like I was your father. Now, who's after you?
Father is.
What?
He brought us to see his bank.
I don't know what we did, but it must have been something dreadful.
He sent the police after us, and the army, and everything.
Michael, don't exaggerate.
Well now, there must be some mistake. Your dad's a fine gentleman and he loves you.
I don't think so. You should have seen the look on his face.
He doesn't like us at all.
Well now, that don't seem likely, does it?
It's true.

Let's sit down. You know, begging your pardon, but the one my heart goes out to is your father. There he is, in that cold heartless bank day after day, hammed in by mounds of cold heartless money. I don't like to see any living thing caged up.
Father in a cage?
They makes cages of all sizes and shapes, you know. Bank-shaped, some of them, carpets and all.
Father's not in trouble. We are.

Oh. Sure about that, are you? Look at it this way. You've got your mother to look after you and Mary Poppins and Constable Jones and me. Who looks after your father? Tell me that. When something terrible happens, what does he do? Fends for himself, he does. Who does he tell about it? No one. Don't blab his troubles at home. He just pushes on at his job, uncomplaining and alone and silent.
He's not very silent.
Michael, be quiet. Bert, do you think father really needs our help?
Well, it's not my place to say. I only observe that a father can always do with a bit of help. Come on, I'll take you home.
In every job that must be done, there is an element of fun. You find the fun, and - SNAP - the job's a game!

[singing]
Early each day to the steps of St. Paul's, the little old bird woman comes... In her own special way to the people she calls, come buy my bags full of crumbs. Come feed the little birds, show them you care, and you'll be glad if you do. Their young ones are hungry, their nests are so bare; all it takes is tuppence from you. Feed the birds, tuppence a bag. Tuppence, tuppence, tuppence a bag... Feed the birds, that's what she cries, while overhead her birds fill the skies. All around the cathedral the saints and apostles look down as she sells her wares. Although you can't see it, you know they are smiling each time someone shows that he cares. Though her words are simple and few, listen, listen, she's calling to you. Feed the birds, tuppence a bag. Tuppence, tuppence, tuppence a bag. Though her words are simple and few, listen, listen she's calling to you. Feed the birds, tuppence a bag. Tuppence, tuppence, tuppence a bag.

[singing]
He traveled all around the world, and everywhere he went, he'd use his word, and all would say, "There goes a clever gent!"

[singing]
When dukes or maharajahs pass the time o' day wi' me, I say me special word and then they ask me out to tea!
Oh, supercalifragilisticexpialidocious! Even though the sound of it is something quite atrocious, if you say it loud enough, you'll always sound precocious! Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious!
Well, do you have anything to say, Banks?
Well, sir, they do say that when there's nothing to say, all you can say...
[He feels Michael's tuppence in his pocket, takes it out and looks at it]
Confound it, Banks! I said do you have anything to say?

[begins giggling hysterically]
Just one word, sir...
Yes?
Supercallifragilisticexpialidocious!
What?
Supercallifragilisticexpialidocious! Mary Poppins was right, it's extraordinary! It *does* make you feel better! Hee hee hee hee!
What are you talking about, man? There's no such word!
Oh yes! It is a word! A perfectly good word! Actually, do you know what there's no such thing as? It turns out, with due respect, when all is said and done, that there's no such thing as YOU!
[Mary Poppins measures herself with her tape measure and reads what it says]
As I expected. "Mary Poppins, practically perfect in every way."
It's true that Mavis and Sybil have ways that are winning, and Prudence and Gwendolyn set your heart spinning! Phoebe's delightful, Maude is disarming...
Janice, Felicia, Lydia...
...charming! Cynthia's dashing, Vivian's sweet! Stephanie's smashing, Priscilla's a treat.
Veronica, Millicent, Agnes, and Jane...
...convivial company, time and again. Dorcas and Phyllis and Glynis are sorts I will agree are three jolly good sports, but cream of the crop, tip of the top - It's Mary Poppins, and there we stop!
You *are* the father of Jane and Michael Banks, are you not?
[pause]
I said, you *are* the father of Jane and Michael Banks.
Well, really - yes, of course. And you brought your references, I presume; may I see them?
Oh, I make it a point never to give references. a very old-fashioned idea, to my mind.
Is that so? We'll have to see about that one then, won't we?
play games, all sorts. Well, I'm sure the children'll find my games *extremely* diverting.
Now this paper, where did you get it from? I - I thought I tore it up.
you must be kind. I *am* kind, but *extremely* firm.
[looking suspicious]
Have you lost something.

[banging his head against the fireplace flue]
Ah! Yes, you see... I thought that...

[singing]
I feel a surge of deep satisfaction, much as a king astride his noble steed.
[speaks]
Thank you.
[sings]
When I return from daily strife, to hearth and wife, how pleasant is the life I lead!
Dear, it's about the children...
Yes, yes, yes.
[sings]
02. Consistent is the life I lead!
George, they're missing!
Splendid, splendid.
[sings]
It's grand to be an Englishman in 1910! King Edward's on the throne, it's the age of men! I'm the lord of my castle, the sovereign, the liege!
[speaks]
I treat my subjects, servants, children, wife with a firm but gentle hand, noblesse oblige.
[sings]
03, and the heirs to my dominion are scrubbed and tubbed, and adequately fed. And so I'll pat them on the head, and send them off to bed. Ah, lordly is the life I lead!
[speaks]
Winifred, where are the children?
They're not here, dear.
What? Well, of course they're here! Where else would they be?

[singing]
So when the cat has got your tongue, there's no need for dismay! Just summon up this word, and then you've got a lot to say! But better use it carefully or it could change your life...
For example...
Yes?
One night I said it to me girl, and now me girl's me wife.
[Wife gets angry and hits him with tambourine]
Ow! And a lovely thing she is, too.
[Wife smiles]
Close your mouth, please, Michael. We are not a codfish.
What did I tell ya? There's the whole world at your feet. And who gets to see it but the birds, the stars, and the chimney sweeps.

[talking about Mary Poppins]
We better keep an eye on this one. She's tricky.
Our first game is called Well Begun is Half-Done.
I don't like the sound of that.
Otherwise titled Let's Tidy up the Nursery.

[to Jane]
I told you she was tricky.
Mary Poppins, we won't let you go!
Go? What on earth are you talking about?
Didn't you get sacked?
Sacked? Certainly not. I am never sacked!
Oh, Mary Poppins!
Hurrah, hurray, hurray, hurray, hurray, hurray...
Neither am I a Maypole. Kindly stop spinning about me.

[singing]
Chim Chiminy, Chim Chiminy, Chim Chim Chiree! When you're with a 'sweep, you're in glad company.
Never was there a more happier crew, than them what sings Chim Chim Chiree Chim Chiroo! Chim Chim Chiminy Chim Chim Chiree Chim Chiroo...
All right, I'll do it myself!
Do what?
Bit o' magic!
A bit of magic?
It's easy! Let's see... You think.
[he, Jane, and Michael do so]
You wink.
[they do so]
You do a double blink.
[they do so]
You close your eyes... and jump!
[They jump onto the drawing, nothing happens]
Is something s'posed to happen?
Bert, what utter nonsense!
[gives an exasperated sigh]
Why do you *always* complicate things that are really quite simple? Give me your hand please, Michael. Don't slouch. One... two...
[They jump into the chalk picture]
Good morning, father!

[grumbles]
'Morning.
Mary Poppins taught us the most wonderful word!
Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious!
What on Earth are you talking about, supercal... super... or whatever the infernal thing is?
It's something to say when you don't know what to say.
Yes, well, I always know what to say.

[singing]
We're clearly soldiers in petticoats, and dauntless crusaders for women's a-votes! Though we adore men individually, we agree that as a group they're rather stupid.
[On the failure of their previous nanny]
I'm sorry, dear, but when I chose Katie Nana, I thought she would be firm with the children. She looked so solemn and cross.
My dear, never confuse efficiency with a liver complaint.
That's a piecrust promise. Easily made, easily broken.
You're a man of high position, esteemed by your peers.
[sings]
And when your little tykes are crying, you haven't time to dry their tears... And see their thankful little faces smiling up at you... 'Cause their dad, he always knows just what to do...
Well, look - I...
Say no more, Gov'ner.
[sings]

You've got to grind, grind, grind at that grindstone... Though childhood slips like sand through a sieve... And all too soon they've up and grown, and then they've flown... And it's too late for you to give - just that spoonful of sugar to 'elp the medicine go down - medicine go dow-wown, medicine go down.
[speaks]
Well, goodbye, Gov'ner. Sorry to trouble you.
[Bert exits, whistling "A Spoonful of Sugar"]
a nanny for two adorable children."
Adorable. Well that's debatable, I must say.

[singing]
If you want this choice position, have a cheery disposition...
Jane, I don't...
Rosy cheeks, no warts...
That's the part I put in!
Play games, all sorts. You must be kind, you must be witty, very sweet, and fairly pretty...
Well of all the ridiculous...!
George, please!
Take us on outings, give us treats, sing songs, bring sweets. Never be cross or cruel. Never give us castor oil or gruel. Love us as a son and daughter, and never smell of barley water.
I put that in, too!

If you won't scold and dominate us, we will never give you cause to hate us. We won't hide your spectacles so you can't see, put toads in your bed, or pepper in your tea. Hurry, nanny! Many thanks! Sincerely...
Jane and Michael Banks!
Just a moment, Mary Poppins. What is the meaning of this outrage?
I beg your pardon?
Will you be good enough to explain all this?
First of all, I would like to make one thing quite clear.
Yes?
I never explain anything.
[exits]

[singing]
With tuppence for paper and strings, you can have your own set of wings! With your feet on the ground you're a bird in flight, with your fist holding tight to the string of your kite! Oh, oh, oh, let's go fly a kite, up to the highest height! Let's go fly a kite, and send it soaring! Up through the atmosphere, up where the air is clear! Oh, let's go... fly a kite!
Shut the window. That bird is giving me a headache.
Yes sir.
[to the bird]
Quiet! You're giving the master a headache!
I suggest you have this piano repaired. When I sit down to an instrument, I like to have it in tune.
But, George, you don't play.
Madam, that is entirely beside the point!

[singing]
These silly words, like...
[speaks and stammers]
Superca... superca... superca...
Supercallifragilisticexpialidocious.
Yes, well done! You said it!
Awk, that's gratitude for you. Didn't even say goodbye?
No, they didn't.
Look at them! You know, they think more of their father than they do of you!
That's as it should be.
Well, don't you care?
Practically perfect people never permit sentiment to muddle their thinking.
you don't fool me a bit!
Oh, really?
Yes, really. I know exactly how you feel about these children, and if you think I'm going to keep my mouth shut any longer, I'll...
[she clamps his mouth shut]
That will be quite enough of that, thank you.

[watching Bert, Albert, Jane, and Michael laugh together on the ceiling]
Why, it's the most disgraceful sight I've ever seen, or my name isn't Mary Poppins.
Speakin' o' names, I know a man with a wooden leg named Smith.
What's the name of his other leg?
[he, Bert, Jane, and Michael laugh]
We can't have them gallivanting up there like kangaroos, can we?
As a matter of fact, since you hired Mary Poppins, the most extraordinary things seem to have come over the household.
Is that so?
Take Ellen, for instance. She hasn't broken a dish all morning.
Really? Well, that is extraordinary.
Oh, George, you didn't jump into the river. How sensible of you!
[Mr. Banks kisses her]

[into phone]
It's all right, sir, he's been found! No, *alive*! Or so I presume, he's a-kissin' the Mrs. Banks.
I've been so worried, what happened at the ba...
[Mr. Banks picks her up and whirls her around]
I've been sacked! Discharged! Flung into the street!
[singing]
A spoonful of sugar makes the medicine go down! Tra-la-laaa-lalalalala!
Gone off his crumpet, that's what he's done. Dotty as you please.
[first lines]
All right, ladies an' gents! Comical poem! Suitable for the occasion, extemporized and thought up before your very eyes! All right, 'ere we go!
[sings]
Room 'ere for everyone. Gather around.
[speaks]
The constable - responstable! Now 'ow does that sound?
[no response]
Hm.
[dashes over to Miss Lark, sings]
'Ello, Miss Lark, I've got one for you.
[speaks]
Miss Lark... likes to walk... in the park... with Andrew!
[Andrew barks, then Bert tips his hat to him]
Hello, Andrew.
[turns to Mrs. Corry, sings]
Ah, Mrs. Corry, a story for you.
[speaks]
Your daughters were shorter than you - but they grew!
It reminds me of me brother. He got a nice cushy job at a watch factory.
At a watch factory? What does he do?
He stands about all day... and makes faces!

[laughing hysterically]
He makes faces in a watch factory!
Uncle Albert, I got a jolly joke I saved for just such an occasion. Would you like to hear it?

[sobbing]
I'd be so grateful.

Well it's about me granddad, see, and one night he has a nightmare. He was so scared, he chewed his pillow to bits. Bits. In the morning, I says, "How you feel, Granddad?" He says, "Oh, not bad. A little down in the mouth."
[Bert laughs, Uncle Albert sobs harder]
I always say there's nothing like a good joke.

[sobbing]
No, and that was nothing like a good joke.

[on phone]
That's what I said, sir. Go fly a kite!
[pause]
Well, no, sir, no. I didn't mean you *personally.*
Ah, there you are, Banks. I want to congratulate you. Capital bit of humor, wooden leg named Smith!
[pauses looks a bit confused]
Or, Jones, whatever it was. Father died laughing!
Oh, I'm so sorry, sir!
Oh no, nonsense, nothing to be sorry about! Never seen him happier in his life. He left an opening for a new partner.
[puts a new carnation into Banks' buttonhole]
Congratulations.
Oh thank you, sir, thank you very much indeed!
[kisses Mrs. Banks]
[Uncle Albert had been asked if there is a way to get down from being up in the air]
There is a way. And frankly, I don't like to think of it, because you have to think of something sad.
Then do get on with it, please.
Yesterday, when the lady next door answered the door, there was a man there, and the man said to the lady, "I'm terribly sorry, I just ran over your cat."
[Jane and Michael descend from being up in the air]
Oh, that is sad.
The poor cat.
And the man said, "I'd like to replace your cat." And the lady said, "That's all right with me, but how are you with catching mice?"
[then they all burst out laughing and Jane and Michael re-ascend back to the tea table in the air]
Never judge things by their appearance... even carpetbags. I'm sure I never do.
People who get their feet wet must learn to take their medicine.
disorder, catastrophe! Anarchy! In short, you have a ghastly mess!
I beg your pardon, are you ill?
I hope not.

Speaking of weather, the other day when it was so cold, a friend of mine went to buy some long underwear. The shopkeeper said to him, "How long do you want it?" And my friend said, "Well, from about September to March."
I want it to feed the birds.
Fiddlesticks, boy! Feed the birds and what have you got? Fat birds! But...
[sings]

If you invest your tuppence wisely in the bank, safe and sound, soon that tuppence, safely invested in the bank, will compound! And you'll achieve that sense of conquest, as your affluence expands! In the hands of the directors, who invest as propriety demands!

[singing]
Just a spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down, the medicine go down, the medicine go down. Just a spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down, in the most delightful way.
Bert'll take care of you, just like I was your own father. Now who's after you?
Father is.
[repeated line]
Spit-spot!

[singing]
Stay awake, don't rest your head. Don't lie down upon your bed. While the moon drifts in the skies... Stay awake, don't close your eyes. Though the world is fast asleep, though your pillow's soft and deep, you're not sleepy as you seem; stay awake, don't nod and dream... Stay awake... don't nod... and... dream.
[last lines]
Goodbye, Mary Poppins, don't stay away too long.
But you're always saying that you wanted a cheerful and pleasant household.
Winifred, I should like to make a slight differentiation between the word cheerful and just plain giddy irresponsibility.
Now this im-posin' edifice what first meets the eye is the 'ome of Admiral Boom, late of His Majesty's Navy. Likes his house ship-shape, he does. Shipe-shape and Bristol fashion at all times!
[the Admiral blows his whistle]
Time gun ready?
Ready and charged, sir.
Three minutes and six seconds.
Aye, aye, sir.
What he's famous for is punctuality. The whole world takes its time from Greenwich, but Greenwich, they say, takes its time from Admiral Boom.
[to Admiral Boom]
Wotcher, Admiral!
Good afternoon to you, young man. Where are you bound?
Number 17. Got some parties 'ere in town what wants to see it.

[to Binnacle]
Enter that in the log.
Aye, aye, sir.
storm signals are up at number 17. Bit of heavy weather brewing there.
Thanks, sir. Keep an eye skinned.
[continues walking]
Here we are, 17 Cherry Tree Lane, home of George Banks Esquire.
[screaming and shouting is heard from the house]
heavy weather brewin' at number 17 and no mistake.
Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.

[Going to see the bank]
Remember that the bank is a quiet and decorous place, and we must be on our best behavior.
But I thought it was your bank.
Yes, well, I'm one of the junior officers, so in a sense it is. Sort of.

[as Jane and Michael run down the path in the chalk drawing]
Don't fall and smudge the drawing!
There's something wrong, the bank won't give someone their money.
Well, I'm going to get mine. Come along, young man, every penny!

Up where the smoke is all billowed and curled / 'Tween pavement and stars is the chimney sweep world / When there's hardly no day, nor hardly no night / There's things half in shadow and halfway in light / On the rooftops of London / Coo, what a sight!
Kindly do not attempt to cloud the issue with facts.

[singing]
A man has dreams of walking with giants. To carve his niche in the edifice of time. Before the mortar of his seal has a chance to congeal... The cup is dashed from his lips! The flame is snuffed a-borning... He's brought to wrack and ruin in his prime.
In 1773, an official of this bank unwisely loaned a large sum of money to finance a shipment of tea to the American colonies. Do you know what happened?

Yes, sir. Yes, I think I do. As the ship lay anchored in Boston Harbor, a party of the colonists dressed as red Indians boarded the vessel, behaved very rudely, and threw all the tea overboard. This made the tea unsuitable for drinking. Even for Americans.
Precisely. The loan was defaulted. Panic ensued within these walls. There was a run on the bank.
From that time to this, sir, there has not been a run on this bank - UNTIL TODAY. A run, sir, caused by the disgraceful conduct of your son. Do you deny it?
I do not deny it, sir, and I shall gladly assume responsibility for my son.

[saluting]
View halloo!

[also saluting]
Oh, yes, definitely. A view halloo.
View halloo?
[the horseman blows his bugle and the others pursue the fox]
Faith and begora, 'tis them Redcoats again!

[singing]
Our daughters' daughters will adore us and they'll sing in grateful chorus, "Well done, sister suffragettes."

[seeing the chimney sweeps dancing on the rooftops]
We're being attacked by hottentots!
Bert'll take care of you; like I was your own father. Now, who's after you?
Father is.
What?

[about his chalk drawings]
Not Royal Academy, I suppose. Still better than a finger in the eye, ain't they?
I'll try to do better next time.
Next time? My dear, you've engaged six nannies in the last four months. And they've all been unqualified disasters.
What's all this? What's all this? What's all this? What's all this?
Glorious day, Mr. Binnacle! Glorious! No one sleeps this morning. Put in a double charge of powder.
A double charge? Aye aye sir!
Shake things up a bit, what?
That's a funny sort of bag.
Carpet.
You mean to carry carpets in?
No, made of.

[measuring Michael with her magic tape measure]
Just as I thought - 'Extremely stubborn and suspicious.'
[Jane laughs]
I am not!
See for yourself.

[reading]
'Extremely stubborn and sups... '
Suspicious. Now you, Jane.
[measures Jane]
Hmm. 'Rather inclined to giggle, doesn't put things away.'
[Michael laughs]
[Andrew the dog comes up to Mary Poppins and starts barking]
Not so fast please, I can't understand a word you're saying.
[Andrew barks slower]
Again? Oh, the poor man!
[Andrew barks again and sneezes]
Bless you.
[Andrew barks again]
Why yes, of course, there's not a moment to lose. I'll go straightaway! And thank you very much.
[Andrew barks]
What did he say?
He said 'You're welcome.'
What else did he say?
I don't think he said anything!
You know best, as usual.
[Mary Poppins is leaving]
She doesn't care what happens to us.
She only promised to stay until the wind changes. Isn't that right Mary Poppins?
Will you be good enough to fetch my hatstand please?
Mary Poppins, don't you love us?
And what would happen to me, may I ask, if I loved all the children I said goodbye to?
While stand the banks of England, England stands - whoa, whoa...!
[Mr. Dawes lurches forward, the others steady him]
When fall the banks of England... ENGLAND FALLS!
[Mr. Dawes falls backward; the rest of the Board of Directors have to catch him]

[observing the queue of prospective nannies]
Ghastly looking crew, I must say!

[sees the time]
Excuse me, POSTS, EVERYONE, PLEASE!
[cannon fires]

[seeing Jane and Michael running in the alley]
Come with me, m'dears! Granny'll 'ide you!
[Katie Nana is trying to leave]
I said my say, and that's all I'll say. I've done with this house forever.
Well, hip-hip-hooray! And don't stumble on the way out, dearie.
You see, Michael, you'll be part of Railways through Africa.
Exactly.
Dams across the Nile.
The ships, tell them about the ships.
Fleets of ocean greyhounds.
More, tell them more!
Majestic self-amortizing canals.
Oh, it fires the imagination!

[singing]
Plantations of ripening tea all from...
prudently, thriftily, frugally invested in the...
To be specific...

[singing]
In the Dawes, Tomes, Mousley, Grubbs, Fidelity Fiduciary Bank.

[snatching Michael's tuppence away]
Welcome to our joyful family of investors!
An outing with father?
Yes.
I don't believe it!
He's never taken us on an outing before.
He's never taken us anywhere!
However did you manage it?
Manage what?
You must have put the idea in his head somehow.
What an impertinent thing to say! Me, putting ideas into people's heads? Really!
Where's he taking us?
To the bank.
Oh Michael, the city! We'll see all the sights and father can point them out to us!
Well, most things he can. Sometimes a person we love, through no fault of their own, can't see past the end of his nose.

[after Mr. Dawes Sr. snatches his tuppence away; screaming]
GIVE IT BACK!
[Michael launches himself forward to get his tuppence back, sparking chaos]
[the house is filled with chimney sweeps]
Aaaahhhh! They're at it again!
Enough is as good as a feast.
[seeing Mary Poppins for the first time]
Perhaps it's a witch!
Of course not - witches have brooms!

[reading the advertisement]
Now about my wages; the reference here is very obscure.

[dazed]
Very obscure.
We must be clear on that point, mustn't we?
Yes, we must indeed.
I shall require every second Tuesday off.
Every Tuesday.
[Banks stares into the fireplace]
On second thoughts, I believe a trial period would be wise.

[looks closely at him]
Hmm. I'll give you one week - I'll know by then.

[Banks is unaware that the other nannies have disappeared]
Ellen?
Yes sir?
Tell the other applicants they may go, the position has been filled.
The others, sir?
Yes, the others! How many nannies does she think we need in this house?
[Ellen opens the door; the only one outside is the dog Andrew]

[to Andrew]
The position has been filled.

[tasting Mary Poppins' magic medicine]
Lime cordial, delicious!
Strawberry! Mmm.
Rum punch! Quite satisfactory.
[hiccups]
Silence please, it's time to go to sleep.
Oh we couldn't possibly go to sleep, so many lovely and excited things happened today!
Did they?
Yes! When we jumped into Bert's chalk picture!
And we rode the merry-go-round, and the horses jumped off...
And we all went riding down the country side!
[they jump up and down shouting riding cries; Mary Poppins acts indifferent]
Really?
Mary Poppins, don't you remember? You won the horse race!
A respectable person like me, in a horse race? How dare you suggest such a thing!
But I saw you do it!
Now not another word or I shall have to summon a policeman! Is that clear?
Glorious day, Mr. Binnacle, Glorious! No one sleeps this morning! Put in a double charge of powder!
A DOUBLE charge? Aye, Aye, Sir!
Shake things up a bit, what?
A proper kite needs a proper tail, don't you think?
Coo, there's a whole queue of nannies outside, sir. Shall I show them in?
00 it shall jolly well be. You see? 12 seconds to go. 10... 9... 8...
Yes, sir.
I have told you time and time again, Ellen, that I dislike being hurried into things.
